basics.name: Qian Wang
basics.label: Computational Scientist | Biochemist
basics.summary: A highly skilled scientist with a Ph.D. in Biochemistry and extensive research experience in structural biology, enzymology, and biophysics. Currently pursuing a Master's in Computer and Information Technology to bridge the gap between life sciences and computational methods. Proven track record of high-impact publications, project leadership, and mentoring.

work.name: College of Staten Island, CUNY
work.summary: Led research projects on metalloprotein dynamics and enzyme mechanisms. Managed and trained undergraduate and Ph.D. students.
highlights: Investigated catalytic mechanisms of cupin dioxygenases using kinetic and spectroscopic methods.
Elucidated metal-binding dynamics and allostery in S100 proteins using NMR spectroscopy and MD simulations.
Coordinated research training for over 10 undergraduate and 7 Ph.D. students by 2025.

education.institution: The Graduate Center, City University of New York (CUNY)

publications.name: Proton Transfer via Arginine with Suppressed pKa Mediates Catalysis by Genitisate and Salicylate Dioxygenase
publications.publisher: The Journal of Physical Chemistry B
publications.summary: Demonstrated the role of a conserved arginine as a proton shuffler in dioxygenase catalysis through pH-dependent kinetics and thermodynamics.

publications.name: Calcium mediated static and dynamic allostery in S100A12: Implications for target recognition by S100 proteins
publications.summary: Revealed how calcium binding regulates the structure and dynamics of S100A12, affecting its function in immune response.

publications.name: Oxygen Activation in Aromatic Ring Cleaving Salicylate Dioxygenase: Detection of Reaction Intermediates
publications.summary: Characterized transient reaction intermediates using a substrate analog, providing insights into the dioxygen binding mechanism.

publications.name: Dynamic regulation of Zn (II) sequestration by calgranulin C
publications.summary: Explored the pH- and calcium-dependent modulation of zinc binding in S100A12, relevant to its antimicrobial activity.

publications.name: Ca (II) and Zn (II) cooperate to modulate the structure and self-assembly of S100A12
publications.summary: Demonstrated metal-ion cooperation in inducing reversible self-assembly of S100A12, impacting its interactions with target proteins.
